etymologies: Old English man(n), (plural) menn (noun), mannian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch man, German Mann, and Sanskrit manu ‘mankind’

notes.text: Traditionally, the word man has been used to refer not only to adult males but also to human beings in general, regardless of sex. There is a historical explanation for this: in Old English, the principal sense of man was “a human being”, and the words wer and wif were used to refer specifically to “a male person” and “a female person”, respectively. Subsequently, man replaced wer as the normal term for “a male person”, but at the same time the older sense “a human being” remained in use. In the second half of the 20th century, the generic use of man to refer to “human beings in general” (as in reptiles were here long before man appeared on the earth) became problematic; the use is now often regarded as sexist or old-fashioned. In some contexts, terms such as the human race or humankind may be used instead of man or mankind. Certain fixed phrases and sayings, such as time and tide wait for no man can be easily rephrased (e.g., time and tide wait for no one). Alternatives for other related terms exist as well: the noun manpower, for example, can usually be replaced with staff or crew, and in most cases, the verbal form to man can be expressed as to staff or to operate

definitions: an adult male human being

examples.text: a small man with mischievous eyes
the men's semi-finals

definitions: a male member of a workforce, team, etc.

examples.text: over 700 men were made laid off
CNN's man in India
Johnson took the ball past three men and scored

definitions: ordinary members of the armed forces as distinct from the officers

examples.text: he had a platoon of forty men to prepare for battle

definitions: a person's husband, boyfriend, or male lover

examples.text: the two of them lived for a time as man and wife

definitions: a male person associated with a particular place, activity, or occupation

examples.text: a Harvard man
I'm a solid union man

definitions: a person with the qualities traditionally associated with males, such as bravery, spirit, or toughness

examples.text: I'm more of a man than you'll ever be

definitions: a male pursued or sought by another, especially in connection with a crime

examples.text: Inspector Bull was sure they would find their man

definitions: a manservant or valet.
a vassal.
a human being of either sex; a person

examples.text: God cares for all races and all men

definitions: human beings in general; the human race

examples.text: places untouched by the ravages of man

definitions: a male individual; one

examples.text: a man could buy a lot with eighteen million dollars

definitions: a type of prehistoric human named after the place where the remains were found

examples.text: Cro-Magnon man

notes.text: in singular, with adjective or noun modifier

definitions: a group or person in a position of authority over others, such as a corporate employer or the police

examples.text: it was a vicarious way of powerless people being able to stick it to the Man

definitions: white people collectively regarded as the controlling group in society

examples.text: he urged that black college athletes boycott the Man's Rose Bowl

definitions: a figure or token used in playing a board game.

phrases.text: make a man out of someone
separate the men from the boys

definitions: (of personnel) work at, run, or operate (a place or piece of equipment) or defend (a fortification)

examples.text: the firemen manned the pumps and fought the blaze

definitions: provide someone to fill (a post or office)

examples.text: the chaplaincy was formerly manned by the cathedral

definitions: fortify the spirits or courage of

examples.text: he manned himself with dauntless air

phrases.text: make a man out of someone
separate the men from the boys

definitions: used, irrespective of the sex of the person addressed, to express surprise, admiration, delight, etc., or for emphasis

examples.text: man, what a show!

phrases.text: make a man out of someone
separate the men from the boys
